Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: They handle a busy checkout with a long queue during peak hours.
Story: I stood behind the register, my hands moving automatically as I scanned groceries and counted change. The line stretched past the candy racks, and my manager’s eyes flicked over every time I hesitated. Each beep of the scanner reminded me to stay focused, to keep the line moving, to not make mistakes. But my phone buzzed in my pocket, a message from my stepmother: “Don’t forget, you’re leading the family ceremony tonight. It means a lot to your dad.” I could almost hear her voice, heavy with expectation, reminding me how important it was to honor our family’s traditions, to show I belonged. My stomach twisted. I wanted to make them proud, to prove I was part of the family, but I couldn’t just leave the register. The customers grew impatient, sighing and tapping their feet, while my mind raced between the demands of my job and the weight of my family’s hopes. I felt pulled in two directions, each role demanding all of me, and I didn’t know how I could possibly choose.
